item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

We are heartbroken over the loss of ten lives during the horrific attack in Boulder yesterday. Our deepest sympathies go out to those whose loved ones lost their lives, were injured, or were otherwise impacted by this tragedy.

As we work toward concrete avenues for change, we are committed to supporting the victims and their loved ones, and helping our fellow Coloradans work to heal the scars that too many tragedies like this one have left on our state.

item.title: Counselors, Not Cops: Heidi’s son J.L. was labeled as a...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Counselors, Not Cops: Heidi’s son J.L. was labeled as a problem child in preschool. Instead of receiving help and understanding for his anxiety and sensory issues, he was punished and restrained multiple times by SROs. The stigma of constant SRO calls and suspensions instead of accommodations made J.L. feel worse about himself than ever. No child should ever feel worthless — especially in school. Read more here: https://aclu-co.org/heidi-laursen-and-her-son-j-l/

item.title: “I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,”...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

“I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,” Shandie said about J.J., her 16-year-old son who has autism. “Why not call me first? I could’ve helped de-escalate the situation.” After many times being kicked off of school grounds at random, J.J. was ticketed for harassment after making a teacher feel "uncomfortable." Shandie was never made aware of the situation by the school. Instead, she would later receive a call from a police officer. Read more about Shandie and J.J.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/shandie-harris-and-her-son-j-j/

item.title: Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their neighborhood schools. That was until the day her 11-year-old son A.V., who has autism, ended up handcuffed in the back of a police car for hours, sobbing, injured, and traumatized when school resource officers decided to intervene in a situation they didn't understand and were not equipped to handle. Read more about Michelle and A.V.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/michelle-hanson-and-her-son-a-v/

item.title: Schools with mental health services see improved attendance...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Schools with mental health services see improved attendance rates, better academic achievement, and higher graduation rates.

But nationwide, 90 percent of students are in public schools that fail to meet the minimum recommended student-to-counselor ratio.

Instead, funding for police in schools has been on the rise. It’s time we reverse these trends. Students need counselors, not cops.
